solution_line_template: We know that Josh must be {years_married} years older than his age when they got married, therefore he is {years_married} + {josh_age_at_marriage} = <<{years_married}+{josh_age_at_marriage}={josh_current_age}>>{josh_current_age} years old today

If their current combined age is {combined_age_factor} times the age Josh was when they married ({josh_age_at_marriage}), then their total combined age is {combined_age_factor} * {josh_age_at_marriage} = <<{combined_age_factor}*{josh_age_at_marriage}={combined_current_age}>>{combined_current_age} years
That means that Anna must be {combined_current_age} - {josh_current_age} = <<{combined_current_age}-{josh_current_age}={anna_current_age}>>{anna_current_age} years old today

If they married {years_married} years ago, Anna must have been {anna_current_age} - {years_married} = <<{anna_current_age}-{years_married}={anna_age_at_marriage}>>{anna_age_at_marriage} years old when they married
